subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: brief survey of reading research
msgSnippet: First, Many thanks to whoever posted the link to the article.  It was fascinating! I speak and read quite quickly an inflected language (Esperanto.)  I don t
messageBody:
First, Many thanks to whoever posted the link to the
article. It was fascinating!

I speak and read quite quickly an inflected language
(Esperanto.) I don't read it quite as fast as
English, but I think this is just because I've got 30
years more English experience than Esperanto. I will
say that Esperanto uses the accusative case to provide
it much greater flexibility in word order than English
has. For example, in English "I am drinking milk" can
be pretty much said and written only in that word
order. Esperanto is perfectly happy with "Mi trinkas
lakton," "Lakton trinkas mi," "Mi lakton trinkas,"
etc. The accusative really doesn't seem to come in to
word recognition, more like meaning recognition or
part-of-speach recognition. I don't know if this
helps.

Regarding Abijads like Arabic or Hebrew (see
www.omniglot.com), I'd be interested to find out if
reading is faster in Arabic when the vowels are
included than when they are not.

Interesting stuff!
delrayva

--- Jon Zuck <jz@...> wrote:

> Interesting question, Jeff.
>
>
> I really doubt the importance of phonetic
> orthography in reading speed,
> at least with mature, avid readers who are well past
> the sounding-it-out
> stage. And I imagine the length of some words in
> German might slow
> things down a bit--it's better to have
> *Fahrvergn�gen* than
> *Hoffnunglosigkeit* in your *G�tterd�mmerung! *
>
> I had a Russian professor tell me that because
> Russian letters have very
> few descenders and ascenders, it makes it harder to
> read than English.
> If I recall, one of the reasons Read designed the
> tall and deep letters
> the way he did was to increase the number of
> descenders/ ascenders for
> easier reading. (But dyslexics got the shaft!)
>
> Another thing that might be interesting to consider
> would be grammatical
> redundancy, do inflected languages, where the
> gender, number and case of
> nouns and adjectives have to match read faster than
> those like English
> with few grammatical endings, or does the redundacy
> get in the way?
>
> I have a suspicion that the alphabetic languages
> which might be most
> difficult would be Hebrew and Arabic, since in
> ordinary printed
> material, vowels are not indicated. A lot more has
> to be inferred by
> context than in European languages. Anyone know of
> any studies yea or nay?
>
> Regarding the misspelling in the Lord's Prayer. . .
> my bad. (forgive me
> my trespasses!) :-[
>
> Jon
>
>
>
> jeff_smith_8992 wrote:
>
> >--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "ouphrontis"
> <allen_rouse@y...>
> >wrote:
> >
> >
> >>this may be of some interest to the group.
> >>
> >>via slashdot
> >>
>
>>http://www.microsoft.com/typography/ctfonts/WordRecognition.aspx
> >>
> >>
> >
> >
> >I just finished reading the article "The Science of
> Word Recognition "
> >(by Kevin Larson) ... thanks for posting the link
> to the web site.
> >
> >With regard to the Read alphabet, I found this
> statement very interesting:
> >
> > "It is well known that words that have a
> consistent spelling to sound
> >correspondence such as mint, tint, and hint are
> recognized faster than
> >words that have an inconsistent spelling to sound
> correspondence such
> >as pint."
> >
> >If this is true, given enough practice, we should
> be able to read text
> >written in QuikScript more rapidly than text
> written in the normal,
> >orthodox alphabet. Has anyone become proficient
> enough in reading
> >QuikScript text that they would say they can read
> it faster than they
> >can read regular text? Any estimates of how much
> time and practice it
> >might take reach this level?
> >
> >Also, in some languages, words are spelled much
> more phonetically than
> >is English (a quick search on the internet says
> German and Japanese
> >are two such languages). Does anyone know whether
> or not people that
> >use these languages can actually read at faster
> rates? Could the
> >average German read a Harry Potter novel in less
> time than an average
> >American?
> >
> >Jeff
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>

Grego VAJDMAN
Aleksandrio, Virginio, Usono

First, Many thanks to whoever posted the link to the
article.  It was fascinating!

I speak and read quite quickly an inflected language
(Esperanto.)  I don't read it quite as fast as
English, but I think this is just because I've got 30
years more English experience than Esperanto.  I will
say that Esperanto uses the accusative case to provide
it much greater flexibility in word order than English
has.  For example, in English "I am drinking milk" can
be pretty much said and written only in that word
order.  Esperanto is perfectly happy with "Mi trinkas
lakton," "Lakton trinkas mi," "Mi lakton trinkas,"
etc.  The accusative really doesn't seem to come in to
word recognition, more like meaning recognition or
part-of-speach recognition.  I don't know if this
helps.

Regarding Abijads like Arabic or Hebrew (see
www.omniglot.com), I'd be interested to find out if
reading is faster in Arabic when the vowels are
included than when they are not.

Interesting stuff!
delrayva
